item.title: Trump’s Greenland U-turn, Syria clashes force Kurds into retreat & China ‘brings home the bacon’
item.description: Is Donald Trump’s retreat from tariffs and military threats over Greenland - a NATO reset or a tactical pause? Syria edges toward reunification but at a major cost to the Kurds – and IS group fighters escape. Plus how a farm girl’s plea from rural China went hog-wild online.

item.title: Surprise jobs report boosts chance of February rate rise
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Johnathan McMenamin from Barrenjoey and Adam Dawes from Shaw and Parnters as Australia's unemployment rate falls from 4.3% to 4.1% in December increasing the chance of an interest rate rise in a fortnight.

item.title: Australia Day 2026: Here’s what's open over the long weekend
item.description: Most shops will be open but in some states they are subject to restricted hours. In one state car and boat dealerships will close.

item.title: 'Left out and ostracised': The social media ban's uneven execution — and other effects
item.description: It's been six weeks since Australians under 16 were banned from most social media platforms. What impact has the ban had?

item.title: US officially withdraws from the World Health Organization
item.description: Global health experts said the withdrawal poses risks for the US, the WHO and the world.

item.title: President Trump keeps world leaders on their toes
item.description: .US President Donald Trump has used the World Economic Forum in Davos to push a new security framework for the Arctic, and signal what he says is momentum towards ending the war in Ukraine. The week has also exposed deep divisions among allies over Greenland and Europe’s role in global security.

item.title: Liberals leader Sussan Ley under pressure after Coalition split | SBS News In Easy English 23 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Liberals leader Sussan Ley under pressure after Coalition split | SBS News In Easy English 23 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Australia’s summers being transformed as climate change drives heatwaves
item.description: Australian summers are undergoing what scientists call a "total transformation," with a new study from World Weather Attribution revealing the country can now expect heatwaves every five years on average. The study's researchers say climate change made Australia's blistering heatwave in early January five times more likely, and there's an urgent need for the country to adapt to changed conditions. The warning comes as the country's south-eastern states prepare for what's forecast to be a prolonged, severe heatwave starting this weekend.

item.title: What next - if anything - for the Coalition?
item.description: The Coalition’s unity has reached a new low following what's being described as a 'terminal' breakdown between key frontbenchers, marking their third significant split since the 2025 election. While leadership maintains that the door remains open for future cooperation, analysts suggest the in-fighting is further alienating a public that is increasingly turning toward minor parties and independent alternatives.

item.title: Is the A$ headed for 70USc?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Tony Sycamore from IG Markets about the day's sharemarket action as the Australian dollar and gold price charge towards new milestones.

item.title: Allowed to beg, forbidden to study: Why conditions for Afghan women are worsening
item.description: Despite an injection of more than $260 million in Australian aid, the situation for women in Afghanistan remains 'bleak'.

item.title: Rights for women deteriorating four years after Taliban takeover in Afghanistan
item.description: It’s been more than four years since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan - and according to human rights organisations, the situation for women and girls is only getting progressively worse - with a near-total exclusion from most public employment and education. The United Nations has warned the country is expected to remain one of the world’s largest humanitarian crises for the year ahead.

item.title: Aussie survivor through to next round after Naomi Osaka pulls out of Australian Open
item.description: Maddison Inglis is the last remaining home hope in the Australian Open women's draw.

item.title: After a night out, men and women face very different heart health risks
item.description: Alcohol consumption can lead to a range of health issues, and your risk level can change based on a range of factors.

item.title: Do you know where your food is really from? This Australian scientist does
item.description: Millions of people globally fall ill each year, from unsafe or contaminated foods. Some is due to food fraud, the act of purposely selling fake, mis-labelled or substituted food products for financial gain. Australian scientists have developed new ways to combat this multi-billion dollar problem.

item.title: Fighting fakes and food fraud, this team knows where your festive dish really comes from
item.description: Almost five million people in Australia fall ill each year from unsafe or contaminated food. Australian technology is helping combat this growing global problem.

item.title: Heatwave, fires and a cyclone in WA: 'Severe and long-lasting' weather shapes long weekend
item.description: Record-breaking temperatures, not seen since the Black Summer bushfires, are expected to prevail over the coming week.

item.title: Australian veterans, RSL respond to Trump's 'profound insult' of US allies' soldiers
item.description: Australians have joined a chorus of disgust across Europe after Trump's statement on Thursday.

item.title: 'They think we're billionaires': This couple inherited a manor. It's been anything but idyllic
item.description: Inheriting property is often complex. When Anne-Sophie and Olivier inherited a 500-year-old château, it presented some unique challenges.

item.title: A century ago, the average Australian was a 24-year-old man. Who is it now?
item.description: Australia celebrates its national day on Monday, but do we really know who we are?

item.title: A Royal Commission has been called. Now what?
item.description: .After weeks of political pressure, the Prime Minister this month announced a Royal Commission into the rise in antisemitism and factors behind the second-deadliest mass shooting in Australian history. It is the latest of a series of Royal Commissions into wide-ranging issues, but what is a Royal Commission and what does it do?

item.title: Man charged over 'abhorrent' threat to Sydney mosque
item.description: The material posted to Sydney's Lakemba Mosque singled out Muslims, Middle Eastern communities, Indigenous people and left-wing politicians.

item.title: Albanese names 'outstanding' replacement for Rudd as US ambassador
item.description: Anthony Albanese has tapped a defence boss and experienced diplomat for the coveted role in Washington DC.

item.title: The Aussie dollar has reached a 15-month high. What does this mean for us?
item.description: A strong Australian dollar could be welcome news for overseas travellers and household budgets.

item.title: See the full list: Here's who's been awarded Australia Day honours in 2026
item.description: Nearly 950 Australians have been recognised this year.

item.title: Astronaut Katherine Bennell-Pegg named Australian of the Year
item.description: The 2026 Australian of the Year winners have been announced at the National Arboretum in Canberra. Thirty-three finalists from astronauts to doctors have been recognised for their contributions to Australian society.

item.title: Alex Pretti's parents say 'lies' being told about their son as Trump officials defend shooting
item.description: Footage appears to contradict Trump officials' claim that Alex Pretti was brandishing a gun and resisting officers when he was shot.

item.title: 'I have two homes': Five migrants share what being Australian means to them
item.description: Hailing from all around the world, these five migrants share why they're grateful to be Australian, despite social cohesion challenges.

item.title: Emergencies declared, flights grounded, millions lose power as deep freeze hits US
item.description: A massive winter storm has swept across large parts of the United States, bringing heavy snow, ice and dangerously cold temperatures to states from Texas to New England. The storm has so far caused more than a million people to lose power, and thousands of flights have been grounded. Nearly 20 states have now declared weather emergencies, as the National Weather Service warns of continued hazardous conditions in coming days.

item.title: 'Lived to help': Grief and outrage in Minneapolis after ICE kills ICU nurse Alex Pretti
item.description: United States Federal Agents have shot and killed another person in Minneapolis, just three weeks after the killing of Renee Good. With growing demands the government withdraw ICE agents from the city, President Donald Trump has signalled their possible intention to leave.

item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.description: An escalation in immigration enforcement and fatal shootings have put a spotlight on Minneapolis.

item.title: New citizens welcomed to Australia as thousands turn out for rallies across the country
item.description: Around 18,000 people became Australians on Monday, as thousands joined Invasion Day rallies and hundreds attended anti-immigration protests.

item.title: From cat videos to conspiracies — is older people's phone use a problem?
item.description: Some parents' and grandparents' screen time has become a concern. But what do we know about phone use and the ageing brain?

item.title: The common medications that can become 'quite dangerous' on hot days
item.description: Some prescription and over-the-counter medications can make it harder for your body to cool down during hot weather.

item.title: The forecast you might be missing as heat and bushfire smoke build
item.description: Smoke doesn't always stay near the flames. Here's how it can affect air quality and health.

item.title: US border patrol chief, some agents to leave Minnesota following shooting backlash
item.description: The US president earlier said he was on a "similar wavelength" with Minnesota governor Tim Walz after they had a "very good call".

item.title: Israel says remains of final Gaza hostage retrieved
item.description: The recovery of the hostages fulfils a key condition of a US-proposed peace plan and could pave the way for the reopening of Gaza border crossings.

item.title: Family says Canadian teen underestimated dingo danger before K'gari death
item.description: An autopsy revealed Piper James likely drowned, but also uncovered evidence of "pre-mortem" dingo bites.

item.title: Bradman scores again as Baggy Green fetches record price
item.description: A baggy green cap worn by Sir Donald Bradman in Australia's 1947 test series against India has fetched $460,000 at auction. The sale of this rare piece of Australian sporting heritage and history is not quite at the level of the sale of Shane Warne's test cap, which went for just over a million in 2020 to raise money for the Australian Red Cross following the 2019 Black Saturday bushfires. But auctions like this offer a glimpse into another world, where serious money is paid for memorabilia items connected to some of the world's most iconic and historic sporting events.

item.title: Two killed in light plane crash on Gold Coast, sparking bushfire
item.description: Emergency crews were called to a private airstrip north of the Gold Coast after a light plane crashed in bushland.

item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Return of final hostage remains fulfils key condition of peace plan
item.description: Israel says it has recovered the remains of the final hostage held in Gaza, police officer Ran Gvili. The recovery fulfills a key condition of the US-proposed peace plan, and could pave the way for the reopening of the Rafah Crossing between Gaza and Egypt.

item.title: The final Israeli hostage's remains have been recovered in Gaza. What happens now?
item.description: Now that all the living and deceased hostages held by Hamas have been repatriated, the focus shifts to Rafah.

item.title: Australian Open prize pool: Here's how much Alex De Minaur took home
item.description: Alex de Minaur will still walk away with hefty pay after he fell short against world number one, Spain's Carlos Alcaraz.

item.title: Is it too late to jump on the gold and silver bullet train?

item.title: It's a crime most assume doesn't happen in Australia — but schools should be on alert
item.description: Most reported victims are young women and girls — but anyone could be affected, the Australian Federal Police says.

item.title: Protests rocked Iran. Now, 41,000 people face a chilling uncertainty
item.description: A month after Iran's deadly protests, there are grave concerns about the use of capital punishment against thousands who have been arrested.

item.title: I’ve been sober for six years. Adjusting to life without alcohol was ‘excruciating’
item.description: Sobriety podcaster Victoria Vanstone felt like alcohol turned her into a "sandal-wearing ogre". She says her kids deserved better.

item.title: De Minaur says he will 'keep on improving' following Australian Open quarter-final exit
item.description: Following a straight-sets loss to world number one Carlos Alcaraz, Australia's highest-ranked men's player isn't giving up his grand slam hunt.

item.title: Heat reprieve for some but others set for another sweltering day
item.description: A cool change is expected for much of Victoria, while heatwave conditions continue in parts of south-east Australia after record heat.

item.title: Doomsday Clock set closer to midnight than ever before
item.description: For a third year in a row, atomic scientists have moved the Doomsday Clock closer to midnight, the theoretical point of annihilation.

item.description: Isaac Herzog was invited to Australia by Anthony Albanese after last month's terror attack at Bondi which targeted the Jewish community.

item.description: Older iPhones and some Apple Watches could be impacted. Here's the full list.

item.title: 'Mother of all deals': How Trump pushed Europe and India to reach a deal after almost two decades of talks
item.description: India and the European Union say they have reached "the mother of all deals" in a trade agreement that has been in the works for nearly two decades. Subjected to steep tariffs and facing threats of further increases, the two major economies are working to diversify their trade partners.

item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.description: Donald Trump is facing mounting political pressure to soften his administration's aggressive deportation tactics.

item.title: Markets bet on February RBA interest rate rise after hot inflation
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a deep dive into today's higher than expected inflation figures to find out what it means for interest rates and for the sharemarkets with Stephen Wu from UBS, James Gerrish from Market Partners and Stephen Miller from GSFM Funds Management.

item.title: Border agents involved in deadly Minnesota shooting placed on 'administrative leave'
item.description: It comes as Donald Trump said he would "de-escalate" in Minnesota amid mounting political pressure over his immigration crackdown.

item.description: The US president said an "armada" of US warships is now in the Middle East, as Iran threatened a massive response to any strikes.

item.title: Chinese officials heading to Brisbane to investigate hot coffee attack on baby
item.description: Baby Luka has undergone at least eight surgeries since the attack, which left his face and body severely burned.

item.title: US pushes Gaza demilitarisation as pressure mounts on Hamas to disarm
Bomb allegedly thrown at Perth Invasion Day rally investigated as 'potential terrorist act'
item.description: Western Australian police said the Joint Counter Terrorism Team was investigating the incident.

item.title: Grave concerns after one month of anti-government unrest in Iran
item.description: It's been a month since one of Iran's deadliest periods of anti-government unrest in the history of the Islamic Republic. While mass protests have subsided amid a crackdown by security forces, a US-based human rights group has confirmed the deaths of more than 6,000 people, warning the total could stand at more than 20,000. Iran's official death toll is just over 3,000. There are also grave concerns for the tens of thousands who have been arrested.

item.title: Paterson says Ley has 'majority' support, Littleproud challenger speaks as spill motions loom
item.description: Both the Liberal and National leaders are facing threats to their leadership ahead of parliament resuming next week.

item.title: Minns to consider creating public holiday fix for 'underserved' state
item.description: With Anzac Day falling on a Saturday this year, NSW Premier Chris Minns has flagged creating a new public holiday.

item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Trump’s Minnesota flashpoint, Myanmar’s 'sham' election & China recalls its bamboo ambassadors
item.description: President Trump feels the heat as ICE protests spread across the US, as Washington unveils real estate plans for Gaza - but are they based in reality? Plus, Myanmar’s military presses ahead with widely dismissed elections, and China’s panda diplomacy reaches an unbearable level.

item.title: Aly speaks after refusing to welcome Israeli president's visit as nationwide protests planned
item.description: Organisers of nationwide protests argue the Isaac Herzog isn't welcome, while the prime minister has backed his visit.

item.title: No vaccines, no cure, and 'very dangerous'. Should we be worried about Nipah virus?
item.description: Airports across Asia are on alert for the deadly virus.

item.title: A hidden childhood cancer is increasing: what do these children need?
item.description: The Leukemia Foundation is warning more than 400 children a year could face a blood cancer diagnosis within the next decade. The foundation is attempting to raise $12 million through its annual World's Greatest Shave campaign, with funds contributing to research and support services to families impacted by blood cancer.

item.title: Iran has its 'finger on the trigger'. But is it at its 'weakest' as US tensions soar?
item.description: Tensions between the US and Iran are increasing, while reports indicate that the US is bolstering its military presence in the region.

item.title: Could a bubble be about to burst? What to know as gold and silver prices surge
item.description: As prices soar amid global uncertainty, experts weigh in on whether the rally will last.

item.title: The end of doctor shopping? Why the government wants to track your medicines
item.description: An estimated 1.5 million people in Australia experience some kind of harmful side effect from using medicine each year.

item.title: Israel releases 15 Palestinian bodies as truce deal shifts to next phase
item.description: It marks the last hostage-detainee exchange between Israel and Hamas in the first phase of the US-brokered ceasefire.

item.title: Trump claims Putin will halt strikes for one week as Ukraine faces extreme cold
item.description: Ukraine's state weather agency has forecast a drastic dip in temperatures to as low as minus 30C in coming days

item.title: Rafah crossing set to reopen as Gaza patients await evacuation
Nearly 50C: More temperature records smashed as 'heat dome' persists
item.description: Australia claimed all of the top 15 hottest spots in the world over the 24 hours to 8am on Thursday.

item.description: The airspace decision reflects broader efforts by the Trump administration to restore diplomatic engagement with Venezuela.

item.title: EU designates Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps as terrorist organisation
item.description: The EU has formally designated Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps a terrorist organisation, aligning it with groups such as Islamic State and al-Qaida. Tensions between Tehran and Washington are escalating amid one of the deadliest protest crackdowns in Iran’s recent history.

item.title: $219 billion over five years: Government strikes last-minute hospital funding deal
item.description: The recently announced funding allocation was triple the amount of the last agreement, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said on Friday.

item.title: Older Australians waiting longer to access home support services | SBS News In Easy English 30 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Drowning victims' families 'in shock' but grateful after $150k raised in support
item.description: Over $150,000 has been raised to support the families of two men who drowned in NSW, as their communities grapple with loss.

item.title: Hastie says he won't challenge for leadership as Ley gives Nationals one-week ultimatum
item.description: One of Liberal Party leader Sussan Ley's potential challengers has ducked out of the running, saying he doesn't have enough support.

item.title: Is it too late to fix your mortgage interest rate? & Trump ready to announce Fed Chair pick
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Canstar's Sally Tindall to find out if it is too late to fix your home loan interest rate ahead of what's expected to be a rise in official interest rates next week; plus Dianne Colledge from Morgans goes through the day's share market action including a preview of Donald Trump's pick of US Federal Reserve governor which is expected to be made at the weekend.

item.title: 'Are we holding creepy men to account?': The loopholes in image-based abuse laws
item.description: Lawmakers around the world are trying to stamp out image-based abuse, but ubiquitous and evolving technologies make regulation difficult.

item.title: Leader in dementia research shares four ways you can reduce your risk
item.description: Henry Brodaty is a world-recognised dementia researcher. Here, he shares ways you can seek to reduce your risk of developing the disease.

item.title: Australian beef farmers scramble to find new markets as a billion-dollar export hit looms
item.description: New tariffs on Australian beef may cut exports to China by 30 per cent cut this year, according to industry experts. Among those affected is a fifth-generation cattle farmer.

item.title: First cohort of migrants under Tuvalu deal arrive in Australia
item.description: The Falepili Union treaty between Australia and Tuvalu was hailed as a global first-of-its kind, with one provision of the agreement allowing up to 280 Tuvaluans to relocate to Australia each year as rising seas threaten their homeland. The first cohort of migrants under the deal are now arriving in Australia. But with just a small Tuvaluan diaspora here, they're facing a challenge to settle in to their new home, while maintaining a connection to community and culture.

item.title: Fresh Epstein files reference Trump, Gates, Musk, former prince Andrew and Lutnick
item.description: The latest cache related to the late convicted sex offender includes more than three million pages, 180,000 images and 2,000 videos.

item.title: Should Australia rethink its alliance with the United States?
item.description: As Donald Trump’s military threats and trade wars unsettle allies, some experts are calling for a rethinking of Australia's long-standing alliance with the United States. The debate has been sharpened by Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney’s speech at the World Economic Forum, which urged middle power countries to resist compromising their values at the behest of major global superpowers.

item.title: Israel announces Gaza's Rafah border crossing with Egypt to reopen
item.description: Reopening of the crossing was one of the requirements under a US-brokered ceasefire agreed in October between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: The $1 billion problem facing Aussie farmers like Robert
item.description: A fifth-generation NSW farmer is among those 'shocked and disappointed' over new China tariffs on Australian beef.

item.title: 'Protect every solitary moment': The viral app that asks users if they're still alive
item.description: A popular Chinese app aims to address the issue of 'empty nesters' who die and are only found days, weeks, or even months later.

item.title: 'Confusion, disappointment': Upcoming Afghan embassy closure leaves community in fear
item.description: An expert said DFAT's decision to close the Afghan embassy follows a demand from the Taliban.

item.title: Thousands applied for this world-first visa. Now the first have arrived in Australia
item.description: Nearly 300 Tuvaluans can relocate to Australia each year under a new treaty, which was partially designed to assist those affected by climate change.

item.title: Weeks before clothing, remains found in hiker search can be identified
item.description: A renewed search in the Tasmanian wilderness for missing Belgian hiker Celine Cremer has entered its second day.

item.title: Big, thirsty, and 'willing to do anything' for water: Australia's camel chaos
item.description: A joint task force has been set up in central Australia to manage feral camels wrecking 'havoc' in remote communities.

item.title: Working no longer 'number one': How this country is trying to break its overwork habit
item.description: While working hours have fallen and reforms are in place, Japan is still wrestling with a deep-rooted culture of overwork.

item.title: Exhibition described as a milestone for inclusion and representation
item.description: A powerful exhibition featuring photographs and stories of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people with disability has been called a milestone for inclusion and representation. First exhibited at the United Nations in Geneva more than a decade ago, it's now being shown again on home soil in its most accessible format.

item.title: A very long way in 100 years: television hits a century
item.description: 100 years ago Scottish inventor John Logie Baird revealed the first television, called the Televisor, to the world. Those first pictures, flickering images of the head of a ventriloquist's doll, sparked a revolution in social entertainment and culture.

item.title: 'No records of this meeting': Rudd denies meeting Epstein at NYC home
item.description: The former prime minister's denial came after newly-released emails showed Epstein had scheduled to meet Rudd in June 2014.

item.title: Second woman claims Epstein sent her to the UK for sex with former prince Andrew
item.description: The claims have emerged after newly-released Epstein files include images of the former prince crouching over an unidentified woman lying on the floor.

item.title: Abuse survivors led the push for this law reform — now NSW could be the first to act
item.description: NSW could be the first state to abolish "good character" references in court proceedings when laws are introduced next week.

item.title: 'We love this kid so much': Paddle-out at Bondi for young shark attack victim
item.description: The parents of 12-year-old Nico Antic led tributes for their son at Bondi Beach on Sunday after he was killed by a shark last month.

item.title: New seating, leadership drama and key bills — what to expect in parliament’s first week back
item.description: Leadership threats hang over two major parties as politicians head back to Canberra next week.

item.title: Reyna and her family are facing deportation from Australia. Her community is fighting back
item.description: A Queensland family, who have lived in Toowoomba for 14 years, are facing possible deportation from Australia — a visa battle that's caught the attention of their community.

item.title: Over 120 people dead in Pakistan after multiple suicide and gun attacks
item.description: Baloch separatists and the Pakistani Taliban frequently target security forces, but coordinated attacks on this scale are rare.

item.title: My daughter might have hundreds of half-siblings. For this, I feel immense guilt
item.description: Carol's two children were conceived with donor sperm in the late 90s. Decades later, she and her family found out the whole truth.

item.title: 'Dream come true': Carlos Alcaraz secures historic career Grand Slam
item.description: Carlos Alcaraz has defeated Novak Djokovic to win his first Australian Open title.

item.title: Reopening of Gaza's Rafah border crossing expected on Monday, Israel says
item.description: Preparations are underway to open the crossing between Egypt and the Palestinian territory, which was closed in May 2024.

item.title: Police say Dezi Freeman could have died in bushland amid renewed search for fugitive
item.description: Police said the new search was based on intelligence linked to a gunshot reported in the area after the fatal shooting in August.

item.description: Several artists used their acceptance speeches to speak out against US President Donald Trump's immigration crackdown.

item.title: Ayatollah Khamenei warns Trump of broader conflict as the US amasses forces in the region
item.description: Iran's Supreme Leader is warning the United States that any attack on Iran could trigger regional conflict, as US naval presence in the region strengthens. As tensions mount over Iran's protest crackdown and a possible nuclear deal, the United States President says his plans hinge on the success or failure of a deal.

item.title: New search launched for fugitive Dezi Freeman in Victoria | Midday News Bulletin 2 February 2026
item.description: New search launched for fugitive Dezi Freeman in Victoria; data released on the top political spenders at the last federal election; and two staff working with Australia's Winter Olympic team test positive for COVID-19.

item.title: Australia confirms closure of Afghan embassy amid Taliban pressure
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has confirmed plans to close the Afghan Embassy in Australia, leaving many members of Australia's Afghan community on edge. Experts say the decision follows a demand from the Taliban that all embassies under the control of an anti-Taliban ambassador be closed. While some members of the Afghan diaspora in Australia say they expect the closure to have little impact, for others, it's a deeply concerning development.

item.description: David Littleproud remains Nationals leader after a failed spill motion; an Australian woman dies after a skiing accident in Japan; record attendance figures at this year's Australian Open.

item.title: What is behind the surge in support for Pauline Hanson and One Nation?
item.description: Support for One Nation has spiked on the back of Pauline Hanson's anti-immigration stance. But experts say while they have reached an unprecedented 26 per cent in primary support, it is the growing hunger for anti-establishment politics that could be reshaping the Australian landscape.

item.title: The Rafah crossing reopens, but with limited numbers
item.description: The Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt has been reopened. Movement will be limited, but for Palestinians needing medical treatment it offers a critical lifeline. The border has been largely shut since May 2024.

item.title: First Palestinians leave Gaza for medical treatment after Rafah crossing partially reopens
item.description: About 150 people were due to leave Gaza on the first day of the reopening, Egyptian officials said.

item.title: Police suspect mother of top US news anchor was 'abducted' from home
item.description: Police are searching for Nancy Guthrie, the mother of Melbourne-born media personality Savannah Guthrie.

item.title: 'It's now a daily occurrence': Warnings as deaths linked to party drug surge
item.description: Deaths linked to GHB increased by tenfold between 2013 and 2022, according to a new study.

item.title: Sussan Ley praises 'constructive' talks with Nationals leader David Littleproud | Midday News Bulletin 3 February 2026
item.description: Sussan Ley praises 'constructive' talks with Nationals leader David Littleproud; the US Justice Department says it's taken down thousands of documents inadvertently including victim-identifying information; and in tennis, two mothers feature in the Top 10 for first time in rankings history.

item.title: Royals, power and public trust: the Epstein files continue to rock the Establishment
item.description: From London to Oslo, institutions built on tradition and public trust are being tested by demands for transparency, accountability and justice. In Britain, both a former prince and a senior political figure are being urged to answer questions about their past associations with Jeffrey Epstein. While in Norway, a criminal trial involving the Crown Princess’s son is unfolding under intense public scrutiny.

item.title: Police search for Dezi Freeman: 'the largest manhunt we have seen in Victoria'
item.description: A fresh search in Victoria's High Country has begun for accused police killer Dezi Freeman, with detectives now believing the 56-year-old is most likely dead. Mr Freeman is accused of killing two police officers and severely injuring a third after they executed a search warrant on a rural property near the Victorian town of Porepunkah last year. Police are now focusing on a new search area in the vast Mount Buffalo National Park.

item.title: Wong condemns 'horrific use of violence' as Australia imposes fresh sanctions on Iran
item.description: Australia has imposed new sanctions on 20 Iranian individuals and three entities, citing repression and human rights abuses.

item.title: School staff face termination under new hate speech rules | SBS News In Easy English 3 February 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Ley avoids Liberal leadership spill as Nationals consider Coalition 'reset'
item.description: The Nationals want to get the Coalition "settings right" as Ley lays out a pathway forward.

item.title: Pro-Palestinian protests planned despite extended restrictions ahead of Herzog visit
item.description: Demonstrators have criticised the extension of protest restrictions, while NSW Police say the measures are about ensuring community safety.

item.title: Australia's interest rate increased for first time since 2023 | Evening News Bulletin 3 February 2026
item.description: Australia's interest rate increased for the first time in more than two years; former Liberal senator Cory Bernardi joins Pauline Hanson's One Nation party; and in sport, Wallabies Rugby World Cup matches revealed.

item.title: Australia's interest rate increased for first time since 2023 | Evening News Bulletin 3 February 2026
item.description: Australia's interest rate increased for the first time in more than two years; former Liberal senator Cory Bernardi joins Pauline Hanson's One Nation party; and in sport, Wallabies Rugby World Cup matches revealed.

item.title: Australia's interest rate increased for first time since 2023 | Evening News Bulletin 3 February 2026
item.description: Australia's interest rate increased for the first time in more than two years; former Liberal senator Cory Bernardi joins Pauline Hanson's One Nation party; and in sport, Wallabies Rugby World Cup matches revealed.

item.title: Interest rate rise ends two-year pause
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia has ended a two-year hiatus by raising interest rates to 15 per cent, sparking a fierce political debate over whether government spending or private demand is fuelling persistent inflation. While the Treasurer defends the budget and points to external pressures, the Opposition and the Greens argue that current policy settings are punishing everyday Australians and ignoring alternative economic levers.

item.title: The key to a long life? One factor may matter more than we thought
item.description: Some say the study's findings have "important consequences for ageing research", while others believe they are "not too surprising".

item.title: RBA pulls the trigger on rates; gold and silver rebound
item.description: The Reserve Bank of Australia has increased interest rates for the first time since November 2023, hiking the official cash rate to 3.85%. It says it now expects inflation to remain well above its 2-3% target for longer, leaving the door open for further rate increases. For more on this, Stephanie Youssef spoke with HSBC chief economist Paul Bloxham. Despite the decision, the Australian share market finished the session strong, amid a strong global stocks rebound that included a gold and silver price recovery. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mark Gardner, CEO at MPC Markets.

item.title: RBA governor's four reasons for rate hike as major banks react to increase
item.description: The Reserve Bank has hiked the cash rate to 3.85 per cent, with one of the major banks saying it's unlikely to be a "one-and-done".

item.title: 'The digital Wild West': Spain planning to ban social media for under-16s
item.description: Australia became the first country in the world to ban social media for under-16s last year.

item.title: The Australians competing in skimo, a new Olympic sport so steep athletes get 'delirious'
item.description: Two Australians will represent the country in the new sport at the Milano Cortina Winter Olympic Games 2026.

item.title: Clintons agree to testify before Congress as part of Epstein investigation
item.description: The decision to testify was announced days before a planned vote to hold the pair in contempt of Congress.

item.title: The four big banks will pass on the the interest rate rise | Morning News Bulletin 4 February 2026
item.description: The big four banks announce plans to hike interest rates ... the Race Discrimination Commissioner says politicians are undermining progress towards a harmonious society... and a US skiing hero to attempt an incredible Olympic comeback

item.title: Musk says raid on French X offices as part of deepfake probe a 'political attack'
item.description: The billionaire owner of the social media platform has also been summoned for a "voluntary interview" as part of the investigation.

item.title: Musk says raid on French X offices as part of deepfake probe a 'political attack'
item.description: The billionaire owner of the social media platform has also been summoned for a "voluntary interview" as part of the investigation.

item.title: 'Left out': How hate laws leave LGBTIQ+ workers vulnerable
item.description: Nearly half of Australia's LGBTIQ+ workers say they have faced discrimination and harassment in the past year. With hate speech rising in Australia, rights groups say stronger laws and greater legal representation are needed to protect the LGBTIQ+ community from greater harm.

item.title: 'Just keep swimming': Heroic WA teen swam for hours to save family swept out to sea
item.description: Police said 13-year-old Austin Appelbee couldn't be "praised highly enough" after he swam 4km to raise the alarm.

item.title: Nearly nine billion a year: The 'particularly nasty' litter polluting Australia
item.description: Clean Up Australia's annual survey revealed this pervasive source of waste unseated soft plastics as the most prevalent item tossed on the ground.

item.title: Protests over Herzog visit still planned despite restrictions | Midday News Bulletin 4 February 2026
item.description: Protest plans continue amid police restrictions ahead of the Israeli president’s Sydney visit; New South Wales' first female governor honoured with a state funeral; and in football, Arsenal goes through to the English League Cup final.

item.title: Historic defence properties earmarked for sale in bid to raise nearly $2 billion
item.description: Defence Minister Richard Marles said the sites eyed for sale were "vacant, decaying, under-utilised and costing millions of dollars to retain".

item.title: US shoots down Iranian drone that 'aggressively' approached aircraft carrier
item.description: The incident comes as the US ramps up its military presence in the Middle East following a violent crackdown on anti-government protests in Iran.

item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Russia blasts an end to the winter truce with Ukraine
item.description: Russia has ended a winter truce that had it and Ukraine agreeing not to attack each other's energy facilities. The 450-drone and 70-missiles attack comes on the eve of another scheduled round of peace talks.

item.title: Billionaire Clive Palmer to challenge electoral donations cap in High Court
item.description: Palmer's mining company, Mineralogy, funnelled more than $52 million into his party ahead of the federal election.

item.title: Clive Palmer rejects claim revealed in Epstein files | Evening News Bulletin 4 February 2026
item.description: Australian billionaire Clive Palmer rejects the claim in the Jeffrey Epstein files; new research shows First Nations people dying at far higher rates from blood cancer.; in football, Australia formally expresses interest in hosting the 2035 Asian Cup.

item.title: Capital Gains Tax again under the spotlight following latest rate rise
item.description: Following the latest interest rate rise, the Federal Government is facing renewed pressure from unions and economists to reform the 50 per cent Capital Gains Tax ((CGT)) discount, which critics label a "tax avoidance scheme" favouring the wealthiest Australians. While the Treasurer maintains a focus on housing supply, proponents of the reform argue that winding back these concessions could reclaim $20 billion in annual revenue and ease the cost-of-living crisis for the nation’s workforce.

item.title: Kids in jail, rising racism: Australia's 2026 human rights report card
item.description: Human Rights Watch has released its annual report for 2026, highlighting several issues it says have tarred Australia's reputation.

item.title: Kids in jail, rising racism: Australia's 2026 human rights report card
item.description: Human Rights Watch has released its annual report for 2026, highlighting several issues it says have tarred Australia's reputation.

item.title: Mapped: The $3 billion in defence sites the government wants to offload
item.description: The Opposition has accused the government of selling the "heart and soul" of Australia's defence force.

item.title: 'Absolutely abhorrent': Posters of accused Bondi shooter appear in Melbourne
item.description: Victoria Police are investigating the display of posters across Melbourne that depict the alleged Bondi gunman Naveed Akram. About 40 have appeared. featuring the image of the accused shooter and the word Aussie beneath his face. They were put together in the style of artist Peter Drew's 'Aussie' series of street art.

item.title: What's really driving inflation — and why software shares are getting crushed
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Shane Oliver from AMP to figure out the real drivers of inflation; plus Damien Boey from Wilson Asset Management about the day's sharemarket action including a software shares sell-off.

item.title: Artist's work 'hijacked' as posters depicting alleged Bondi gunman appear in Melbourne
item.description: Melbourne lord mayor Nicholas Reece said the copycat posters were deeply offensive.

item.title: Who is Isaac Herzog, and why is his imminent Australian visit controversial?
item.description: Israel's president is set to arrive in Australia soon for a visit hailed by some as "deeply significant", and criticised by others.

item.title: Many Aussies live in multi-generational homes. How is living with parents in your 40s?
item.description: While multi-generational living can come with a lot of benefits, others say most of our houses simply aren't designed for it.

item.title: Your Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics guide: Aussie athletes and how to watch
item.description: Thirty Australian athletes will make their debut at the Milano Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics.

item.title: What's behind Australia's inflation problem — and can you do anything about it?
item.description: Inflation is back in the spotlight after the Reserve Bank hiked rates for the first time in more than two years.

item.title: Human Rights Watch says the US has undermined democracy | Morning News Bulletin 5 February 2026
item.description: A major human rights group report indicates global democracy has been set back 40 years; A third Australian dies on Japan's ski slopes, in a horror season across the nation; And Western Sydney upsets A-League Women leaders Melbourne City 1-nil.

item.title: Man sentenced to life in prison for 2024 attempt on Donald Trump's life
item.description: Ryan Routh tried to assassinate then-candidate Trump on a Florida golf course ahead of the US presidential election.

item.title: Man sentenced to life in prison for 2024 attempt on Donald Trump's life
item.description: Ryan Routh tried to assassinate then-candidate Trump on a Florida golf course ahead of the US presidential election.

item.title: Trump administration to remove 700 immigration officers from Minnesota
item.description: Minneapolis has become a major flashpoint in Trump's immigration crackdown after two fatal shootings in the city by federal agents.

item.title: Mildura has already broken heatwave records. As climate change advances, what comes next?
item.description: For many in Australia's south-east, the day after Australia Day brought sweltering conditions and record temperatures. In Mildura, in Victoria's far northwest, the mercury hit 48.6 Celsius. And when coastal areas enjoyed a reprieve, the inland still had to cope with an extended heatwave that lasted a week. Experts say these kinds of phenomena are going to intensify over time because of the impacts of climate change - but while there has been plenty of coverage of how that impacts on urban centres, regional Australia has not received the same attention. SBS visited Mildura to see how the region felt the heat, and what they're doing to cope with climate change at a local level.

item.title: 'Bloodbath': Mass layoffs at Jeff Bezos-owned Washington Post
item.description: The shrinking of the prominent masthead comes as major media outlets in the US face intense pressure from Donald Trump.

item.title: Iran-US nuclear talks back on, set for Friday in Oman
item.description: Talks will go ahead following weeks of increasing tensions between the two countries.

item.title: Iran-US nuclear talks back on, set for Friday in Oman
item.description: Talks will go ahead following weeks of increasing tensions between the two countries.

item.title: Bondi stabbing inquest findings handed down | Midday News Bulletin 5 February 2026
item.description: A coroner hands down findings from an inquest into the fatal stabbing of six people at Bondi last year; legislation introduced on a National Commissioner for First Nations children; and in sport, Jakara Anthony and Matt Graham named as the Australian flag-bearers for the Winter Olympics.

item.title: Bondi stabbings: 'Major failing' in mental health care of killer, inquest finds
item.description: The coroner said Joel Cauchi's psychiatrist failed to act on warning signs.

item.title: Alleged Invasion Day rally attacker ‘self-radicalised’, WA Police say, declaring terror act
item.description: WA's first terrorism charge has been laid against the man accused of the alleged Invasion Day rally attack in Perth's CBD on 26 January.

item.title: Dozens killed in Israeli strikes, movement paused after Rafah crossing partially reopened
item.description: Fresh Israeli strikes and reported disruptions to patient evacuations have followed the partial reopening of Gaza's Rafah crossing.

item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Police say a suspect has been identified in the disappearance of four-year-old Gus Lamont
item.description: The four-year-old was reported missing from a remote South Australian sheep station in September.

item.title: Police say a suspect has been identified in the disappearance of four-year-old Gus Lamont
item.description: The four-year-old was reported missing from a remote South Australian sheep station in September.

item.title: Trump v Iran, the huge Epstein dump and Melania’s hundred-million-dollar doco bomb
item.description: The US and Iran tussle over talks to stave off more strikes, millions more Epstein documents touch the rich and powerful the world over from Elon Musk to the Norwegian princess-royal and more trilateral talks in Abu Dhabi don’t stop the destruction across Ukraine. Plus, US democracy in danger and what we learned when Melania Trump’s doco hit the cinemas…

item.title: Who's using the capital gains tax discount, and how much does it cost the budget?
item.description: A rise in the cash rate due to stubborn inflation has cast a spotlight on making housing more affordable.

item.title: Perth man charged with terrorism offence | Evening News Bulletin 5 February 2026
item.description: A Perth man charged with a terrorism offence; police have a suspect in the case of missing four-year-old Gus Lamont; and in sport, Australia's Elvis Smylie one shot off the lead at the LIV Golf tournament in Saudi Arabia.

item.title: The cost of cancer: new research highlights the financial toll of treatment
item.description: Almost 99 per cent of Australians diagnosed with cancer incur out-of-pocket expenses, even when accessing public care. That's the shocking finding from the Cancer Council Australia’s latest national survey, which suggests the financial burden arises from both direct medical costs and indirect expenses at every stage of the cancer journey. The cost of accessing care and treatment hits First Nations communities especially hard, with Indigenous Australians ultimately facing a higher mortality rate for blood cancer.

item.title: Democracy is under threat warns Human Rights Watch, set back to the 1980s
item.description: Democracy and the rules-based international order are under threat, according to the latest annual report by Human Rights Watch. There's a particular focus on the United States and what the international body describes as its erosion of human rights, but there is also a spotlight on Australia. Australia's immigration and youth detention policies are listed as 'significant failings', cited as the only Western democracy without a national human rights act.

item.title: Debate over the new role designed to try and help Indigenous kids
item.description: A National Commissioner for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children is being established, a move hailed by advocates as a milestone for independent accountability in closing the gap for youth justice and welfare. However, critics like Senator Lidia Thorpe warn that without federal power to penalise states or compel compliance, the role risks becoming a matter of optics over tangible safety.

item.title: 'Incredibly scary': After Nick's ski accident in Japan, he has a message for travellers
item.description: An Australian who had a near-fatal ski accident in Japan has urged holidaymakers to be aware of risks, following recent deaths.

item.title: Coroner identifies major failings by psychiatrist who treated Bondi Junction attacker
item.description: A psychiatrist who treated the Westfield Bondi Junction attacker has been referred for review by the coroner investigating the mass killing in 2024. New South Wales State Coroner Teresa O'Sullivan criticised the care of Joel Cauchi's former psychiatrist for failing to adequately respond to a schizophrenia relapse in the years before the mass stabbing, which saw six people killed and 10 injured. She has made 23 recommendations, including a call for the Health Ombudsman of Queensland to review the psychiatrist's care and treatment of Joel Cauchi.

item.title: Police investigating after mosque receives second threatening letter
item.description: The Lebanese Muslim Association says community members are increasingly telling them they feel unsafe.

item.title: Software sell-off continues and bitcoin tumbles
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Ben Clark from TMS Private Wealth about the day's market action including a software sell-off in the US which is trickling to Australia, plus what the fall in the bitcoin price says about the economic and investment environment.

item.title: AFP confirms it won't arrest Israeli President Isaac Herzog amid calls for investigation
item.description: The Australian Federal Police has confirmed it has sought independent legal advice about how to handle the president of Israel's upcoming visit to Australia.
